title: 108_s736
content: The Act is titled the "Animal Fighting Prohibition Enforcement Act" and enforces prohibitions on animal fighting under the Animal Welfare Act. The Animal Welfare Act is amended to prohibit the sale, transport, or use of sharp instruments attached to birds for animal fighting ventures. Penalties for violations are increased from 1 year to 2 years. The Animal Welfare Act is amended to increase penalties for violations from 1 year to 2 years. The Secretary or authorized persons will conduct investigations to determine violations, with assistance from various law enforcement agencies. Warrants may be issued by a judge of the United States. The Animal Welfare Act is amended to increase penalties for violations from 1 year to 2 years. A judge of the United States, United States magistrate judge, or judge of a State or tribal court may issue a warrant to search for and seize property involved in a violation of this section. The Animal Welfare Act is amended to increase penalties for violations from 1 year to 2 years. A warrant may be issued to search for and seize property involved in a violation. Any property seized under the warrant shall be held pending court disposition. Animals seized must be stored humanely at an animal housing facility. When animals are seized in a violation, a representative sample is taken for evidence and stored humanely. The remaining animals are kept at the seizure location, provided with humane care, and identified for evidentiary purposes. Care for seized animals is ensured while in custody. While a seized animal is held in custody, necessary care (housing, feeding, veterinary treatment) must be provided. Any property involved in a violation can be forfeited to the United States through court proceedings. On entry of a judgment of forfeiture, a forfeited animal shall be disposed of by humane means as directed by the court. Costs incurred for care of a seized and forfeited animal can be recovered from the owner in the forfeiture proceeding or through a separate civil action. The owner, custodian, or other person claiming an interest in a seized animal can make a claim to the property. The owner, custodian, or other person claiming an interest in a seized animal may prevent disposition by posting a bond for the care of the animal within 10 days of seizure. The owner or other person claiming an interest in a seized animal may renew a bond within 10 days after the previous bond expires, or the animal may be disposed of. An animal may be euthanized if a veterinarian determines it is suffering extreme pain. The Animal Welfare Act is amended to include provisions for movement on Indian tribal land and expanded communication technologies. Authorization of appropriations is also addressed. The Animal Welfare Act is amended to include provisions for movement on Indian tribal land and expanded communication technologies. Authorization of appropriations is also addressed, with necessary sums authorized to carry out the Act. Amendments take effect on the date of enactment of the Act or May 13, 2003.
